Tel.: +48 22 2347991; fax: +48 22 2347991. Graphical abstract Highlights ► A novel catalyst H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2 was characterized and used in toluene nitration. ► On the surface domains of phosphomolybdic acid (HPM) are obtained. ► HPM obtained in the catalysts is more stable than HPM directly supported on SiO2. ► High yield and high selectivity to isomer para-nitrotoluene were obtained. ► The method of catalyst regeneration was developed. A new catalyst, H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2, was prepared by modification of MoO3/SiO2 using phosphoric acid. The characterization of the catalyst was performed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and Raman and Infrared Spectroscopy. Molybdenum oxides in two polymorph forms (α and β) were identified along with phosphomolybdic acid, polymolybdates and polyphosphates in various combinations on the modified surface. The suitability of the catalysts was examined for toluene nitration in the presence of fuming nitric acid. The catalysts were very effective in toluene nitration and the selectivity and toluene conversion depend on the nature of species present on the surface. Since the catalysts have significantly reduced activity in subsequent reactions, a simple process of regeneration was found. The MoO3/SiO2 modification with H3PO4 causes new domains on the surface to be obtained and increases catalytic properties in comparison to unmodified MoO3/SiO2 system. Keywords Nitration Toluene Solid state catalyst Molybdenum oxide Phosphomolybdic acid 1 Introduction Molybdenum oxide is an active and selective catalyst [1] in many reactions belonging to very different types such as reactions with the participation of hydrogen or oxygen (which may be consider as redox processes), isomerization, addition or decomposition, which are classified as acid–base processes. Silica supported molybdenum oxide catalysts are well-known and have been investigated in respect of structure and catalytic properties. They are obtained by ammonium molybdate impregnation on silica gel and calcinations at various temperatures [2,3]. With increase of the calcination temperature the surface structures undergo consecutive changes. At the beginning, at 240°C polymolybdate Keggin structures and domains of two forms of molybdenum oxides, namely α-MoO3 and β-MoO3, are present on the surface. At 300°C the oxides are in majority and at 500°C there is only α-MoO3. Further this oxide is hydrated and transformed into polymolybdate SiMo12H trimers that exhibit properties of strong Brönsted acid. These surface structures of MoO3/SiO2 are able to generate NO2 + cation from nitric agent (e.g. nitric acid) so they can be used as catalysts in the nitration process. The most active catalyst in toluene nitration is 15%MoO3/SiO2 system [4,5]. This amount of MoO3 provides sufficiently high amount of acidic centers to protonate nitric acid. Yield of less than 90wt.% and nitration selectivity to para-nitrotoluene (para-NT) described by the para/ortho isomer ratio (p/o) of about 1 have been reported. In order to improve activity and selectivity of solid catalysts, they are modified with sulfur or phosphorus compounds. Our research is focused on activation of solid catalysts by addition of phosphoric acid. This acid has been used previously for modification of zeolite ZSM-5 and so-obtained catalyst has been used in toluene nitration. Higher activity and selectivity in comparison to unmodified zeolite have been reported [6–8]. Another catalytic systems have been obtained during mixing titania and phosphoric acid in molar ratio of 1:1 [9]. The catalyst works efficiently with nitric acid in the nitration of toluene with average p/o of ca. 1.1. It has been shown that this catalyst is also suitable for nitration of other aromatic compounds, e.g. naphthalene, anthracene. Other reports describe modification of TiO2/SiO2 with H3PO4 [10–12]. Acidic strength of so-obtained catalysts was increased and comparable to that of superacids. The reaction yield and selectivity were higher than that obtained with unmodified catalyst. Another type of modification with phosphate ions involves synthesis of active sites in situ on the support. Research on benzene nitration in the presence of a catalyst prepared by heating ammonium molybdate with ammonium orthophosphate are presented in [13]. In this way the catalytic system consists of ammonium salt of 12-molybdophosphoric acid (heteropolyacid). The catalyst is effective and relatively durable in benzene nitration. Salts of heteropolyacids have also been used in benzene nitration in gaseous phase [14] and satisfactory yield and selectivity have been reported. Heteropolyacids (HPA) are promising solid acids used in homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions [15–18]. They are more active than typical solid acids and therefore they are great catalysts, especially in gaseous phase. Phosphomolybdic acid (HPM) is one of the strongest inorganic acids (pK1 =2) thus it is a great proton donor [19,20]. HPM supported on silica gel (HPM/SiO2) protonates silica surface OH groups and ion pairs of ≡SiOH2 + PM− are formed (PM− is a deprotonated HPM having a Keggin structure). The excess of HPM forms separate domains on the support surface. Our interest encompasses catalytic systems consisting of MoO3 and silica gel (carrier) [4,5]. In connection with the literature data described above, research on and modification of the 15%MoO3/SiO2 catalytic system by phosphoric acid have been performed and is discussed in this paper. The aim of this work was to obtain in situ new structures, i.e. phosphomolybdic acid, on the surface capable of improving catalytic properties. The modified catalytic systems (H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2) were applied to toluene nitration. Catalyst characteristics, and influence of obtained structures on product composition and reaction selectivity is described herewith. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Toluene (pure), fuming nitric acid (pure), silica gel (SiO2), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate [(NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O] (pure), ethylene dichloride (pure), phosphoric acid (85%, pure), magnesium sulfate anhydrous (pure), sodium hydrogen carbonate (pure), phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (ACS reagent). All materials were taken from POCH Gliwice, Poland (except for SiO2 purchased from Mątwy, Poland and phosphomolybdic acid purchased from Sigma Aldrich). 2.2 Methods Analysis of the reaction products was made using gas chromatography with a Perkin-Elmer Auto System XL and a Rxi-5Sil MS (30m×0.53mm×1.5μm) column. The sample of post-reaction mixture was dissolved in 1,2-dichloroethane. The quantitative composition of was determined by internal standard method using peak areas and chlorobenzene as the internal standard (IS). Raman spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Almega Dispersive Raman Spectrometer. Infrared spectra were recorded on Nicolet 6700 interferometer (4000–400cm−1, resolution 4cm−1) as KBr pellets. SEM images were made using a scanning electron microscope FEI Quanta 200 with EDS (Energy Dispersive Spectrometer) EDAX attachment. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover diffractometer. The acidity of the catalyst was determined by measurements of the initial electrode potential and potentiometric titration method [13,21,22]. A suspension of 1g of catalyst in acetonitrile was magnetically stirred for 3h. The suspension was titrated with a solution of 0.05N n-butylamine in acetonitrile. Then the variation in the electrode potential was measured with a pH meter, using a standard glass electrode. 2.3 Procedures 2.3.1 Catalysts preparation To obtain 5g of the catalyst MoO3/SiO2 (pre-catalyst) 0.9g (0.75mmol) of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate was dissolved in 7mL of 3% H2O2. This solution was applied by wet impregnation method on 4.25g of SiO2 (grains 0.6–1mm). First, the catalyst was dried at 110°C. Next it was heated at 300°C for ca. 16h. As a result, 0.75g (5.2mmol) of MoO3 was obtained (the oxide MoO3 constituted 15wt.% of the catalyst mass). The solution of H3PO4 was applied to the pre-catalyst. To enable selection of the amount of H3PO4 to be determined the following reaction was assumed to occur: 12MoO3 +H3PO4 →H3PMo12O40. According to this reaction 30, 100 or 150wt.% amounts of H3PO4 were applied. Next, the amount of H3PO4 with respect to MoO3 mass placed on the silica gel was calculated. These calculations give values of 1.4, 5.7 and 6.4wt.% (0.11, 0.43 and 0.49mmol) of H3PO4 placed on 5g of the pre-catalyst. Re-heating was conducted at 300°C for about 16h. The catalysts modified with 30, 100, and 150wt.% of H3PO4 are denoted as: 1.4%H3PO4, 5.7%H3PO4 and 6.4%H3PO4, respectively. To obtain 5g of HPM/SiO2 catalyst, 0.79g (0.44mmol) of 12-phosphomolybdic acid was dissolved in 13mL of water. The solution was applied to 4.2g of SiO2. The catalyst was dried and heated at 300°C for about 1h. 2.3.2 Regeneration process of 5.7%H3PO4 After the 5.7%H3PO4 catalyst was utilized in the nitration reaction it was washed with solvent and dried at 110°C. A solution of H3PO4 in the same amount as was initially used in the preparation of the catalyst (5.7wt.%, 0.43mmol) was applied to the catalyst. It was dried at 110°C and then heated at 300°C for 1h. 2.3.3 Nitration process Ethylene dichloride as solvent (10mL), 5g of the catalyst and fuming HNO3 (0.28mL, 6.6mmol) were introduced into a three-necked flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, reflux condenser and a dropping funnel. Toluene (0.43mL, 4.0mmol) and solvent (12mL) were placed in the dropping funnel. Upon dropwise addition of the funnel contents (for ca. 10min) the stirring was continued for 2.5h at 25°C. On completion of the reaction the catalyst was filtered and washed off with a solvent. The filtrate was shaken with aqueous sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), then with water, and finally dried over magnesium sulfate (MgSO4). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characteristics of fresh H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2 catalyst To determine the type of the domains that are obtained on the surface of pre- and modified-catalysts Raman (Figs. 1 and 2 ) and IR analysis (Fig. 3 ) were made. Raman spectra were taken from several surface domains. The description of species on the surface of the catalysts are listed in Table 1 [2,21–30]. The characteristic Raman and IR bands confirm that domains of HPM, MoO3 and polymolybdates are present on the surface of all modified catalysts. The pre-catalyst, obtained in the thermal decomposition of ammonium molybdate at 300°C, contains α-MoO3 and traces of polymolybdates. The absence of β-MoO3 signifies that selective decomposition of molybdate to the high-temperature oxide form –α-MoO3– occurs. However, the presence of polymolybdates is indicative of transformation of α-MoO3 into β-MoO3, because β-MoO3 transforms into polymolybdates in the presence of water vapor [19,23,24]. On the XRD pre-catalyst pattern (Fig. 4b) peaks for molybdenum oxide at 2θ angles of 12.8, 23.4, 25.7, 27.3, 33.7, 45.8, 46.3 and 49.3° and for amorphous silica gel (Fig. 4a) a broad peak at 22° [17] occur. Furthermore, in the XRD pattern there is no evidence for polymeric molybdate probably due to their amorphous structure. It is known that about 20% of the total supported molybdenum crystallizes as MoO3 [2]. There is a specific site on the surface of the silica that interacts strongly with the molybdate ion. At high loadings the sites are saturated and the molybdenum atoms exist as heptamolybdate which has almost no interaction with the support. The weakly adsorbed molybdates (above 5wt.% Mo) when heated transform into crystalline MoO3. The rest 80% of the total supported molybdenum exists as amorphous phase monolayer. The oxide and polymolybdates form a smooth surface that is seen in the SEM images in Fig. 5a. Therefore, during catalysts preparation, H3PO4 reacts with α-MoO3 and defective forms of polymolybdates supported on the silica gel. The species obtained on the pre-catalyst surface are supported on the surface, as well as, in the pores. It follows that H3PO4 have various degrees of accessibility to these compounds. For that reason various amounts of H3PO4 have been used to obtain HPM. It has been assumed that only parts of molybdenum compounds are available, all molybdenum compounds are available or part of phosphoric acid is adsorbed on the free surface of the support and therefore an excess of phosphoric acid must be used. The amounts of phosphoric acid used to obtain the catalysts 1.4%, 5.7% and 6.4% H3PO4 assure the molar ratio P: 12Mo of 0.3, 1.0 and 1.5, respectively. Theoretically, molybdenum that will form HPM on the catalyst amounts to 2.4, 8.0 and 10.4wt.%, respectively. These quantities indicate that when HPM is formed as surface ion pairs with silica surface OH groups (≡SiOH2 + PM−) [19,20]. The addition of 1.4% H3PO4 to pre-catalyst causes crystalline α-MoO3 to be formed on the smooth surface composed of domains of HPM and polymolybdates held together by Mo–O–Mo bridges. The presence of these products suggests that the reactions presented in Scheme 1 occur. The oxide in the presence of water slowly transforms into polymolybdates and then in the presence of H3PO4 transforms into HPM. The phosphoric acid must extract the polymolybdates from the smooth layer that covers the pre-catalyst grains and this process causes migration of molybdate species, and further leads to local excess of molybdate concentrations. This results in crystallization of all α-MoO3, that did not undergo the reaction with H3PO4 during catalyst preparation to crystallize. The transformations shown in Scheme 1 take place on silica gel and occur in the presence of water. The amount of water introduced with phosphoric acid is sufficient to initiate these transformations. Since β-MoO3 is not observed, water has to be solely used to form HPM (β-MoO3 can be formed in the presence of excess of water). The Raman spectra of catalyst 5.7% and 6.4% H3PO4 point out that on the surface crystallites of α- and β-MoO3 are present (Fig. 1) and α-MoO3 appears in the majority. In the images (Fig. 5b) of the modified catalyst, sites with crystallites are observed. Importantly, the crystallites have not been seen prior to modification (Fig. 5a). The crystallites are cuboids of 2.5–5μm in dimension. On the XRD pattern (Fig. 4c) only peaks for molybdenum oxide occur [17] and peaks for HPM are not visible. Since the crystallites on the modified surface are composed of MoO3 and not of HPM, the amount of obtained HPM is probably too low for its crystallization. This confirms that HPM is obtained in the form of ion pairs of ≡SiOH2 + PM−. Between crystallites of MoO3 there is a smooth surface composed of domains of HPM, polymolybdates and phosphates (Fig. 2) that did not undergo the reaction and an amorphous layer of α- and β-MoO3 oxides. In the preparation of 5.7% and 6.4% H3PO4 catalyst ca. five times higher amount of H3PO4 is used than in the preparation of catalyst 1.4% H3PO4. Therefore, one may expect all reactions that lead to HPM (presented in Scheme 1) to be greatly intensified especially in the 6.4% case. The presence of β-MoO3 in these systems indicates that HPM undergoes decomposition to this oxide according to the following reaction [17,19–24]: (1) 2 H 3 PMo 12 O 40 ⇄ H 2 O 2 H 3 PO 4 + 24 β ­ MoO 3 Furthermore, transformation of α-MoO3 into β-MoO3 is also possible to occur. However, transformation of α into β occurs also in the preparation conditions but with very low yields, because β-MoO3 is not observed on the surface of the pre- or 1.4%H3PO4-catalysts. With this in mind, it may be accepted that HPM transformation given by reaction (1) is a major source of obtained β-MoO3. Furthermore, silica gel induces destabilization of HPM and simultaneously stabilizes β-MoO3 enabling the rebuilding of the Keggin unit [19–24]. The presence of α-MoO3 on the surface of the 5.7 and 6.4% H3PO4 catalysts points out that only some of α-MoO3 undergoes reactions in the preparation process (despite a greater than stoichiometric amount of H3PO4 is used). Therefore, the transformation of this oxide into polymolybdates is a limiting stage of HPM formation. However, the obtained amounts of HPM ensure its transformation into β-MoO3. The transformations occur via various distorted Keggin structures, oligomeric and polymorphic forms of polymolybdates and defective forms of molybdenum oxides [19–24]. The latter are certainly constituents of the amorphous surface layer placed on the grains of these catalysts so they are not seen in the XRD pattern (Fig. 4c). Not all of α-MoO3 that is present on the pre-catalyst surface undergoes the reaction with H3PO4 and hence there is an excess of phosphoric acid in the 5.7 and 6.4% H3PO4 catalysts. The excess causes domains of polyphosphates to be formed under the preparation conditions. On the surface of the 1.4% H3PO4 catalyst, polyphosphates do not appear. This proves that all of the added phosphoric acid is consumed in the HPM formation. The acidity of the catalysts was measured by the potentiometric titration technique [13,21]. The titration curves are shown in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that modified catalysts have greater acidic strength than pre-catalyst and SiO2, even though all materials (except for SiO2) have a similar number of acidic surface sites. The maximum acidic strength of the surface sites can be described by the initial electrode potential (E i ). For pre-catalyst E i is 561mV and increases for catalysts modified by H3PO4 to: 646mV for 1.4%H3PO4, 665mV for 5.7%H3PO4 and 683mV for 6.4%H3PO4. The acidic strength of the surface sites increases with the amount of phosphoric acid. The increase in acidic strength is caused by the presence of HPM and polyphosphates on the catalyst surface. The increase in acidic strength in the modified catalyst is also attributed to the double bond nature of PO, which strengthens the acid sites via an inductive effect [10]. The 6.4%H3PO4 catalyst contains the highest amount of H3PO4 with considerable excess of the acid on the surface. To summarize, on the surface of the 1.4% H3PO4 catalyst crystallites of molybdenum oxide and HPM, in the form of ≡SiOH2 + PM− ion pairs, are obtained. On the surface of the 5.7% and 6.4% H3PO4 catalysts crystallites of MoO3 and domains of HPM (in the form of ≡SiOH2 + PM− ion pairs) covered by a layer of polymolybdates and polyphosphates are present. The acidity of modified catalysts is increased in comparison to unmodified ones. 3.2 Toluene nitration and effect of reaction environment on 5.7%H3PO4 surface structure To describe the activity of the pre-catalyst (0% of H3PO4) and modified catalysts toluene nitration in the presence of fuming nitric acid was performed. The results of the reactions are listed in Table 2 and they confirm that the catalysts modified by H3PO4 are very effective in toluene nitration. In the presence of fuming nitric acid only 5wt.% conversion of toluene is obtained during nitration. Mononitrotoluenes are the only products. The nitration proceeds owing to the autoprotonation of nitric acid and generation of a nitronium cation NO2 +: (2) 2HNO3 ↔H2NO3 + +NO3 − ↔NO2 + +H2O When water concentration in the system increases to ca. 8% a further reaction proceeds via generation of an oxide, NO, that is formed as a by-product in the oxidation processes. NO reacts with HNO3 to obtain nitrosyl cations (NO+): (3) NO+HNO3 +H+ →NO+ +NO2 +H2O Then the nitrosyl cation substitutes the aromatic ring hydrogen in the electrophilic reaction to provide a nitroso compound which is oxidized to mononitrotoluene. In these conditions only mononitration is possible. Tested catalysts are able to generate nitronium cations (NO2 +) very effectively and almost 100% conversion of toluene is obtained (Table 2). The NO2 + cations are obtained by the protonation of nitric acid by the stronger protonic acid: (4) HNO3 +H+ ↔H2NO3 + ↔NO2 + +H2O The concentration of NO2 + is high enough to introduce even two nitro groups into the toluene molecule. For the most active catalyst (1.4% H3PO4) ca. 15wt.% of dinitrotoluenes is obtained. It is known that when greater than ca. 10% with respect to molybdenum of HPM is directly introduced to a silica gel, complete titration of surface OH groups and formation of separate phase of HPM occur. The obtained catalysts contain proton centers of high acidic strength. The results presented in Table 2 show that the most effective generation of nitronium cations is when the HPM phase is present on the catalyst surface. When catalysts with HPM domains are used, toluene nitration selectivity is higher than with pre-catalyst (p/o increases to 1.32–1.34). Therefore, HPM domains have to be responsible for higher nitration selectivity towards para-NT. HPM placed on the silica gel forms ion pairs. The nitric acid is protonated by the protons that are initially bound to the non-bonding electron pairs of the oxygen atoms of the OH groups present on the silica surface. The protons are then replaced by the generated nitronium cations in order to maintain the ion-pair system on the surface (Scheme 2 [31]). Such a location of nitronium cation is characteristic for solid acids when nitration occurs with higher selectivity to para position. Replacement of nitronium cations for hydrogen cations during nitration causes the surface OH2 + cations to be rebuilt and para-NT to be obtained. The introduction of higher amounts of phosphoric acid to catalysts (i.e. 6.4% H3PO4) leads to decrease in reaction selectivity to para-NT and decrease in the amount of obtained dinitrotoluenes (Table 2). This amount of phosphoric acid causes formation of phosphates and polyphosphates phases. The phosphoric phases should not decrease the amount of ≡SiOH2 + PM− but they probably mechanically cover the surface layer of salts blocking access to them. Higher toluene conversion in the reaction with these catalysts points out that phosphate and polyphosphate phases catalyze toluene nitration. However mononitrotoluenes are mainly obtained and reaction selectivity to para-NT is lower in comparison to the results obtained over other modified catalysts. Relatively high amounts of dinitrotoluene (DNT) are also obtained in the reactions with modified catalysts. DNT is not obtained in the reaction with pre-catalyst. To introduce one nitro group into toluene molecule, a mixture of 100%HNO3–80%H2SO4 is needed, whereas to introduce two nitro groups, a mixture of 100%HNO3–93%H2SO4 should be used [32]. Therefore, one can assign the power (strength) of 93%H2SO4 to OH2 + cations which at the beginning of nitration causes dinitrotoluene formation. The obtained water (during nitronium or nitrosyl cations generation (Eqs. (3) and (4)) causes the reversible reaction of nitronium cations generation to occur which results in hindered DNT formation. In the Raman spectra of the 5.7%H3PO4 catalyst after the first reaction (Fig. 7a) the bands at characteristic Raman shifts indicate a mixture of three molybdenum-species structures: HPM (bands at 990, 960, 890, 600 and 250cm−1), α-MoO3 (820 and 670cm−1) and β-MoO3 (850 and 770cm−1). Thus the reported Raman spectrum suggests that during the reaction a uniform distribution of a layer of oxides and HPM on the catalyst occurs. Crystalline MoO3 is not leached (Fig. 4d) and the part of the structure is maintained despite taking part in the reaction. HPM undergoes decomposition during reaction (1) but the process is reversed in the presence of water and HPM is regenerated during nitration. However, there is a partial destruction of surface ion pairs ≡SiOH2 + PM− which are very active nitration centers. In addition, in the reaction mixture the opening of HPM structure occurs and PO4 3− anion is released, as it happens in the aqueous solution in pH>2 [23] and the part of phosphate ions is leached from the surface as H3PO4. The effect is observed for HPM/SiO2 used in the second reaction (Table 2), when toluene conversion drastic decreases (ten fold). The process of HPM regeneration seems to be less effective in further reactions probably as a result of leaching of phosphate ions, that are templates, on which in the presence of trimolybdic groups of polymolybdates, HPM is formed. Thus, in the subsequent reactions the disappearance of HPM domains is observed as the intensity (Fig. 7b) of the band at 1000–990cm−1 (HPM) decreases whereas the intensity of bands at 850 and 770cm−1 (β-MoO3) increases. On the catalyst mainly β-MoO3 remains. This oxide is not very active in toluene nitration. As a result toluene conversion decreases to 70% and further to 30%. Furthermore, it may be seen that in subsequent nitrations with 5.7% H3PO4 the amount of para-NT decreases as HPM disappears and β-MoO3 forms. It confirms that domains of HPM are responsible for greater selectivity to para-NT. The novel, unavailable-at-the-beginning phases are uncovered and therefore the catalysts are active in the subsequent reactions. 3.3 Effect of regeneration process of 5.7%H3PO4 on surface structure A method for the regeneration process of the 5.7%H3PO4 catalyst was developed. The subsequent nitrations in the presence of regenerated catalysts were carried out. The results are presented in Table 3 . Subsequent regenerations of the catalytic system do not decrease toluene conversion drastically, with conversion of 90wt.% being obtained. The decrease of p/o is noticeable as higher amounts of ortho-NT are obtained. Furthermore, the amount of meta-NT decreases to traces for reaction 9 and 10. The regeneration process enables to reuse the catalyst many times. Raman spectra of regenerated catalyst 5.7%H3PO4 are presented in Fig. 8 . In Fig. 8a the Raman spectrum of the catalyst after it was used in nitration and then heated at 300°C is shown. The bands at 850 and 770cm−1 suggest the presence of β-MoO3. Heating does not cause formation of the original HPM and polymolybdates structures but their further decomposition. The Raman spectra in Fig. 8b and c describe the regenerated catalyst system after addition of H3PO4 and re-heated at 300°C. On the surface there is a mixture of molybdenum oxides (850, 820 and 770cm−1), HPM (1000, 970 and 250cm−1), polymolybdates and polyphosphates (broad bands at 960 and 800cm−1). Fig. 8d presents the Raman spectrum of the catalyst after a tenth regeneration process. Domains of HPM are still present (1000–900 and 600cm−1) along with molybdenum oxide, mainly in α polymorphic form. As a result of the preliminary proceedings, i.e. washing out phosphate ions from the reaction mixture, only β-MoO3 is obtained on the surface (Figs. 5d and 7). It reacts with extra added phosphoric acid and transforms very fast, but not completely, into HPM. Structures of other compounds that are formed are not known yet. Probably, regenerated HPM phases form surface ion pairs and due to their presence the reaction occurs with quite high selectivity to para-NT (p/o =1.31). However, the amount of regenerated pairs is lower than initially and the amount of DNT is relatively low. This description of the catalyst concerns the first three regenerations. In further regenerations the catalyst does not change its activity but reaction selectivity changes. The selectivity is similar to that obtained in the reaction with catalyst covered by phosphate and polymolybdate phases, p/o is 1.1. The presented characteristics of catalysts modified by phosphoric acid allows their usefulness for toluene nitration to be determined. When the reaction selectivity to more desirable para-NT isomer is taken into consideration the best catalyst is the catalyst modified by 5.7wt.% H3PO4. This catalyst gives higher than MoO3/SiO2 conversion of toluene. Furthermore, effective regeneration allows to increase reaction selectivity towards mononitrotoluenes. 4 Conclusions In this paper we have presented a new catalyst system that was obtained by modification of MoO3/SiO2 by phosphoric acid. We have shown that it is possible to obtain in situ HPM domains by heating H3PO4 with MoO3/SiO2. HPM obtained in this way is more stable than HPM directly supported on SiO2. The modified catalytic systems advantageous catalytic properties in toluene nitration in comparison to unmodified system. Complete characterization of the obtained structures and their transformations during nitration have been presented. The underlying pre-catalyst structure of our modified catalyst remains stable allowing HPM and polyphosphates to be recreated on the surface by addition of H3PO4. The catalyst substrate is therefore reusable and provides high efficiency. Significantly this system facilitates the nitration of toluene without the need of using sulfuric acid. There are new possibilities to use HPM as a catalyst in liquid phase reactions. coredata.dc:description: A new catalyst, H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2, was prepared by modification of MoO3/SiO2 using phosphoric acid. The characterization of the catalyst was performed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and Raman and Infrared Spectroscopy. Molybdenum oxides in two polymorph forms (α and β) were identified along with phosphomolybdic acid, polymolybdates and polyphosphates in various combinations on the modified surface. The suitability of the catalysts was examined for toluene nitration in the presence of fuming nitric acid. The catalysts were very effective in toluene nitration and the selectivity and toluene conversion depend on the nature of species present on the surface. Since the catalysts have significantly reduced activity in subsequent reactions, a simple process of regeneration was found. The MoO3/SiO2 modification with H3PO4 causes new domains on the surface to be obtained and increases catalytic properties in comparison to unmodified MoO3/SiO2 system.
coredata.dc:title: Characterization of a novel solid catalyst, H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2, and its application in toluene nitration
